turn out.translation[0].definitions[0].d: to happen in a particular way, or to have a particular result, especially one that you did not expect
turn out.translation[0].definitions[0].e: As it turned out (=used to say what happened in the end), he passed the exam quite easily.
It was a difficult time, but eventually things turned out all right.
It turned out that I was wrong.
That guy turned out to be Maria’s second cousin.
turn out.translation[0].definitions[1].d: to stop the flow of electricity to a light by pressing a switch, pulling a string etc
turn out.translation[0].definitions[1].e: Don’t forget to turn out the lights when you go!
turn out.translation[0].definitions[2].d: if a lot of people turn out for an event, they go to watch it or take part in it
turn out.translation[0].definitions[2].e: About 70% of the population turned out for the election.
Thousands turned out to watch yesterday’s match against Ireland.
turn out.translation[0].definitions[3].d: to force someone to leave a place permanently, especially their home
turn out.translation[0].definitions[3].e: If you can’t pay the rent, they turn you out.
turn out.translation[0].definitions[4].e: The factory turns out 300 units a day.
turn out.translation[0].definitions[5].d: dressed in good, beautiful etc clothes
turn out.translation[0].definitions[6].d: to empty something completely by taking out the contents
turn out.translation[0].definitions[6].e: The policeman made him turn out his pockets.
turn out.translation[0].definitions[7].d: to take out everything in a room, drawer etc and clean the room etc thoroughly
turn out.translation[0].definitions[7].e: Lea decided to turn out the attic.
turn out.translation[1].definitions[0].d: to produce or make a lot of a particular product
turn out.translation[1].definitions[0].e: The factory turns out 300 units a day.
